March 21, 1920.
President Borough of Manhattan.

Second Avenue, west side, north from 2nd Street. The picture also shows the east side of Second Avenue, north from 4th Street.
June 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

41, 43 Second Avenue, west side, between 2nd and 3rd Streets, showing the gateway to the Marble Cemetery, which occupies most of the interior of the block. It should not be confused with the New York City Marble Cemetery on the north side of 2nd Street between Second and First Avenues.

June 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

26 2nd Street, north side, west of Second Avenue.
June 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
2nd Street, north side, east from No. 48, east of Second Ave, showing the Marble Cemetery, of the City of New York, not to be confused with the Marble Cemetery, whose entrance is between Nos. 41-43 on the west side of Second Ave., around the corner.
May 9, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same; viewed westward, to and including Second Ave. Also shown is La Salle Academy (3 buildings west of cemetery), Nos. 44- 50, east of Second Ave. The white building shown at their rear, is the rear of the R.C. Church of the Nativity, (46-48 Second Ave.).
May 9, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

Olivet Memorial Church, and 65, 67, 71, 73 2nd Street, south side, between Second and First Avenues, founded in 1867 by the New York City Mission and Tract Society.
May 9, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Olivet Memorial Church, and 65, 67, 71, 73 2nd Street, south side, between Second and First Avenues, founded in 1867 by the New York City Mission and Tract Society.
May 9, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
19 to 1 East 2nd Street, south side, west from a point midway between Second Avenue and the Browery, and to the latter (right), showing an old row of 2 1/2-story structures that may have faced the Marble Cemetery, which is now located in the center of the next block north, and hidden from view by surrounding buildings. The four on the right, Nos. 11 to 5 are of frame construction with
brick fronts.
December 9, 1937
George D. Chinn
(2)
The same row of buildings during demolition for a parking lot and a gas station. From E. lst Street a smmall alley (Extra Place) led to the rear of these structures and provided a back
entrance. Note the Third Avenue "El" on the Bowery.
June 29, 1938
P. L. Sperr

(1)
19 to 1 East 2nd Street, south side, west from a point midway between Second Avenue and the Browery, and to the latter (right), showing an old row of 2 1/2-story structures that may have faced the Marble Cemetery, which is now located in the center of the next block north, and hidden from view by surrounding buildings. The four on the right, Nos. 11 to 5 are of frame construction with
brick fronts.
December 9, 1937
George D. Chinn
(2)
The same row of buildings during demolition for a parking lot and a gas station. From E. lst Street a smmall alley (Extra Place) led to the rear of these structures and provided a back
entrance. Note the Third Avenue "El" on the Bowery.
June 29, 1938
P. L. Sperr

Second Ave., west side, between East 2nd and 3rd Streets, showing the entrance to the New York Marble Cemetery between Nos. 41 and 43 Second Ave. This burial place is hidden in the center of this block and surrounded by buildings; those which appear in the back, face onto the east side of the Bowery. On the north side of East 2nd Street between First and Second Aves is another "Gods Acre" bearing the name "The New York City Marble Cemetery" which is not to be confused with this shown; though both belong to the same Corporation.

February 5, 1938.

George D. Chinn.

folder: 2nd Street Between 1st and 2nd Avenues, Manhattan, N.Y.
